title: 104_s1241
content:
The Public Broadcasting Financial Independence and Family Viewing Act of 1995 establishes guidelines for family-friendly programming, prohibits the use of federal funds for indecent or nudity-inclusive programs, and emphasizes the importance of public broadcasting providing educational and entertaining content suitable for family viewing. SEC. 4. PUBLIC INTEREST.

Section 396(a) of title 47 is amended to emphasize that public broadcasting should provide educational, cultural, informational, and entertaining programming suitable for family viewing.

SEC. 5. SPECTRUM FLEXIBILITY.

Regulations will allow public broadcast license holders to use their spectrum for ancillary services, as long as they continue to provide public broadcast programming for free and maintain their commitment to public broadcasting.

SEC. 6. SCHEDULE FLEXIBILITY. SEC. 6. SCHEDULE FLEXIBILITY. The Commission will allow public broadcast license holders to use their broadcast schedule between 1 a.m. and 6 a.m. for non-public broadcast programming on a leased basis or commercially sponsored programming, as long as the proceeds benefit public broadcasting, existing commitments are maintained, and fees for non-public broadcasting are at market rates. SEC. 7. ENHANCED UNDERWRITING. Amends sections of title 47 to allow for the promotion of products or services through a call to action or the provision of price information. SEC. 8. SATELLITE, COMMON CARRIER AND OTHER FORMS OF PROGRAM DISTRIBUTION. Public Broadcasting programming can be distributed for a fee via various technologies, with proceeds benefiting public broadcasting exclusively. Public Broadcasting programming can be distributed through various technologies for a fee, with proceeds benefiting public broadcasting exclusively. The Commission may approve frequency exchanges between public and commercial broadcasters for the benefit of the national public broadcasting system. Agreements for programming should include provisions for public broadcasting to share in benefits from ancillary products related to the broadcast. The General Accounting Office will review the operations of public broadcasting entities and make recommendations for improvement. They will also study the feasibility of merging public broadcasting with international broadcasting operations. Additionally, educational rates will be addressed. SEC. 12. The General Accounting Office will study merging public broadcasting with international broadcasting. SEC. 13. Public broadcast licensees qualify for educational telecommunications service rates for public broadcasting purposes.
